results.title: Jakob Gimpel, pianist: program No. 13
results.creator_credit: Paul Gordon, George Moskov and Official Films
results.brief_description: A Felix Mendelssohn recital performed by Polish-American pianist, Jakob Gimpel, featuring “Etude in F Major” (Opus 104, No. 2), and two songs without words - “Lost illusions” (Opus 67, No. 2) and “Spinning song” (Opus 67, No. 4).

results.title: Damn Yankees = What Lola wants
results.creator_credit: Stanley Donen, George Abbott and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Joe Boyd (Robert Schafer), an aging business man and avid baseball follower makes a deal with the devilish Applegate (Ray Walston) to relive his youth and regain a position in the Washington Senators. In the process Boyd becomes the young, handsome “Shoeless” Joe Hardy (played by Tab Hunter), a star baseball player that earns his success at the cost of Boyd’s soul. Boyd has a plan however - or so he thinks, a plan which seems destined to fail when Applegate sends in a beautiful decoy (Gwen Verdon) to seduce the baseball player. It all boils down to a tense game against the New York Yankees in which winning the pennant will also win back Joe’s soul. Based on the Broadway play of the same name and written specially for the screen by Richard Adler, who co-authorised all the original songs with Jerry Ross.

results.title: Dama a sobachkoi = Lady with the little dog
results.brief_description:
In Yalta, at the end of the 19th century, an unhappily married woman goes on a holiday alone, walking her dog daily to relive her ennui. A banker named Dimitri, beguiled by Anna’s beauty, admires her from afar, himself suffering in a miserable arranged marriage. The two embark upon a hopeless affair, which Anna assumes will end with the holiday. Dimitri returns to Moscow but distracted by the memory of Anna, contrives to see her again. Back in Saratov, Anna is equally as depressed and most surprised when Dimitri arrives at a concert she is attending. Drawn together by their misery, the lovers continue to meet intermittently in the hope of salvaging a schism of love from their ruined lives. Displaying a fondness for the manners and social mores of turn of the century Russia, Heifits contrasts the brightness of Yalta in summer (symbolic of the passionate beginnings of the affair), with the cold Moscow winter. The low-key direction and emotional undercurrents of the film adequately reflect the power of Chekhov’s prose.

Credits: Director, writer, Josef Heifits ; photography, Andrei Moskvin, D. Meschiev ; music, Jiri Sternwald.
Cast: Iya Savvina, Aleksei Batalov, Nina Alisova, Pantelejmon Krymov, D. Zebrovv, M. Safonova.

results.title: Mondo Lugosi: a vampire's scrapbook
results.brief_description: A compilation of movie trailers and excerpts from many of Bela Lugosi’s horror films dating from the 1930s to the late 1940s. Born Bela Ferenc Dezso Blasko on 20 October 1882 in Lugos, Hungary, Lugosi began his acting career on stage performing with the Budapest Academy of Theatrical Arts and as a leading actor with Hungary’s Royal National Theatre. By 1920 Lugosi had moved across to Germany where he began appearing in films. He emigrated to America in 1921 playing bit parts in obscure films until finally in 1931 he broke into the Hollywood scene, cast in the title role of the horror film, “Dracula”. Numerous other films of similar genre followed, including “Murders in the Rue Morgue” (1932), “The Invisible ray” (1936), “The Wolf man” (1941), “The Ghost of Frankenstein” (1942), “Frankenstein meets the Wolf Man” (1942) and “The Body snatcher” (1945). Trailers of these films, along with interviews and appearances by Lugosi on American television programs “Tribute to a star” and “You asked for it” are contained in this video. Includes scenes with Boris Karloff, Frances Drake, Claude Rains, Betty Boop and many other stars of the time.

results.title: Dalekmania
results.creator_credit: Kevin Davies, John Farbrother and Amity Productions
results.brief_description: It’s 1965 in England: the BBC TV serial ‘Doctor Who’ is presently on every home TV. A 6 part Dalek adventure has just finished - Dalekmania is at it’s height. Milton Subotsky and Max J. Rosenberg competing against ‘Hammer Horror’, decide to cash in on the Dalekmania - they release their first Dalek movie : “Dr. Who and the Daleks”. No one had ever seen Daleks in colour, so in the wide-screen film, Daleks of all colours dominated the screen. Peter Cushing played the Doctor, unlike the TV serial. Although the film was separate from the BBC production - it was highly successful. So successful they made another movie : “Dalek - Invasion Earth 2150 A.D.”, a year later whilst Daleks were still on people’s minds. In this short film we see snippets and trailers from these two movies; hear interesting stories from the actors involved; and those wonderful toys and memorabilia that have become extremely collectable.

results.title: Dalai Lama in Australia production
results.brief_description:
An audio visual recording of the following events as part of the visit to Australia in May 2002 by His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama of Tibet:

4.00 pm Sunday 19th May 2002: Public Talk by Dalai Lama

8.30 am Monday 20th May 2002: Teaching by Dalai Lama: Atisha’s,
A Lamp to the Path to Enlightenment.

11.15 am Monday 20th May 2002: Victorian Secondary Schools
Event with the Dalai Lama and Sigrid Thornton as MC.
5 Students will ask questions of the Dalai Lama.

2.00 pm Monday 20th May 2002: Teaching by the Dalai Lama:
Atisha’s Lamp to the Path to Enlightenment

9.30 am Tuesday 21st May 2002: Teaching by the Dalai Lama:
Atisha’s Lamp to the Path to Enlightenment

2.00 pm Tuesday 21st May 2002: Teaching by the Dalai Lama:
Atisha’s Lamp to the Path to Enlightenment

9.30 am Wednesday 22nd May 2002: Semkye and Chenrezig Jenang
Empowerment by the Dalai Lama

2.00 pm Wednesday 22nd May 2002: Teaching by the Dalai Lama:
Atisha’s Lamp to the Path to Enlightement

results.title: Jamaica Inn
results.brief_description: Maureen O’Hara is a beautiful damsel in distress who must contend with the madness of the evil Squire Pengallon, the chief of a band of cut throats who lures ships onto the rocks in Victorian times. The opening of the film sets the tone: a “Jamaica Inn” sign half in gloom buffeted by wind and rain. Charles Laughton is memorable as the evil Squire. Rated: PG

results.title: Jamboree for friendship
results.brief_description: Boy Scouts from one hundred countries take part in the varied activities at the Twelfth Boy Scout Jamboree in Idaho, summer 1967. Youths swap talk and ideas, show each other crafts, national dances and customs, attend religious services, take part in a rodeo and a spectacular night campfire - making friends from around the world.

results.title: The Letter
results.creator_credit: Carolyn Johnson, Anne Delaney and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
A visually beautiful film about the pain, fear and courage of the 19th century novelist Fanny Burney, who had her right breast removed without anaesthetic in 1811. It is based on a letter Fanny wrote to her sister some months later. Cast includes Skye Wansey as Fanny Burney and Rachel Blake as the voice of Fanny Burney.
The original letter now resides in the New York Public Library.
